Title: Eradicating Institutionalization: A Moral and Economic Imperative

Institutionalisation, a system where children are separated from their families and placed in residential institutions, has enabled the unjustifiable incarceration of 8 million children worldwide. This issue is particularly poignant at this time of year, as many of these children experience harsh conditions, such as poverty, malnutrition, and trauma, in institutions that are often well-intentioned but inadequate. According to the CEO of Lumos, an organization dedicated to eradicating institutionalization, the solution is not to improve the quality of these institutions, but to replace the system altogether.

The effects of institutionalization are dire, with children being less likely to be educated, physically or mentally well, and more likely to be abused or trafficked. The impact of not having a dedicated carer is particularly severe, causing stunting, developmental delays, and psychological trauma. Even well-resourced institutions have a profound effect on children, and the solution is to provide alternative solutions such as fostering, adoption, or family-based care.

The good news is that this is a solvable problem. According to Lumos, the institutionalization of children can be eradicated by 2050 through a combination of inclusive education and healthcare, support for vulnerable families, and a shift in the way we think about keeping families together. This is an economic as well as a moral imperative, as it is far more cost-effective to support a child in a family than in an institution.

International donors play a significant role in this process, and the principles they promote and the issues they support can make a significant difference. The success of Lumos in countries such as Moldova, the Czech Republic, and Bulgaria, where the number of children in institutions has been significantly reduced, is a testament to the power of this approach. The social media campaign #Letstalklumos, launched by JK Rowling, aims to raise awareness and make this issue a global priority.

In a personal commitment, JK Rowling has taken on the role of president of Lumos for life, with the goal of eradicating institutionalization in our lifetime. This is a crucial time for making progress towards this goal, with the EU, the US, and the Global Alliance for Children setting a precedent for other donors. Everyone has a role to play in making this vision a reality, and it is an issue that can be solved in our lifetime.
answers: JK Rowling makes the case today that millions of kids around the world are living in appalling conditions—the stuff of Grimms' fairytales—in institutions that are supposed to be caring for them. Rowling wants to change that, not by improving these orphanages with "pretty murals" or teddy bears, but by eliminating them altogether, she writes in the Guardian. The big challenge is providing support for often-poor families who think they have no choice but to place their child in such an institution. If a child's biological family isn't up to the task, then foster families can step in. But Rowling argues that institutions are absolutely the wrong answer. Rowling has started a charity called Lumos (yes, after one of her Harry Potter spells), and writes that it has made genuine progress in reducing new placements in countries such as Bulgaria, Moldova, and the Czech Republic. She wants to raise awareness and donations with campaigns like this one. "I recently committed to becoming president of Lumos for life," writes Rowling. "It is my dream that, within my lifetime, the very concept of taking a child away from its family and locking it away will seem to belong to a cruel, fictional world." Click for her full column.

"Colon cancer has traditionally been thought of as a disease of the elderly," says lead author Samantha Hendren. "This study is really a wake-up call to the medical community that a relatively large number of colon cancers are occurring in people under 50." Using government data on almost 260,000 colon-cancer patients from 1998 to 2011, the study also says younger patients more often have advanced cancer and undergo surgery (72% compared to 63% of patients over 50). The young are also more likely to use radiation therapy (53% to 48%) and have a slight advantage in surviving for five years (68% to 67%). Younger people are more likely to have advanced colon cancer partly because they get tested after noticing symptoms (like colon blockage, bleeding, and anemia), while people over 50 are advised to begin screenings, says Hendren. "Unfortunately, these symptoms are often ignored by the patient or doctor or ascribed to something like hemorrhoids," a scientist adds, per Reuters. Hendren's team conducted the study after noticing a rise in colon cancer among young people, Medical Daily reports, but that spike remains unexplained. Physical inactivity, obesity, smoking, and "an effect in our environment" are all possible causes, a Harvard professor says. More screenings for young people might help, but the yield would be low because under-50s are still less likely to get colon cancer. "This would be a big and costly change," says Hendren, who recommends "a lot of research" be done first. (A new killer is expected to top cancer by 2050.)

Researchers previously believed the Early Stone Age marked by large, primitive tools (hand axes and cleavers) made way for the Middle Stone Age and its smaller tools (spearpoints and blades) around 280,000 years ago.
